tips.content: React components are regular JavaScript functions, but their names must start with a capital letter or they won’t work!
JSX and React are two separate things. They’re often used together, but you can use them independently of each other. JSX is a syntax extension, while React is a JavaScript library.
JSX elements directly inside a map() call always need keys!
Event handlers must be passed, not called! onClick={handleClick}, not onClick={handleClick()}.
Events propagate upwards. Call e.stopPropagation() on the first argument to prevent that. Events may have unwanted default browser behavior. Call e.preventDefault() to prevent that.
To update some state multiple times in one event, you can use setNumber(n => n + 1) updater function.
Treat all state in React as immutable.Instead of mutating an object, create a new version of it, and trigger a re-render by setting state to it.
You can use the {...obj, something: 'newValue'} object spread syntax to create copies of objects. Spread syntax is shallow: it only copies one level deep.
In React, you will be using slice (no p!) a lot more often because you don’t want to mutate objects or arrays in state. Splice mutates the array
